message.content: This question requires knowledge of ecological processes. Decomposition is the process by which organic matter is broken down into simpler substances by decomposers, such as fungi and bacteria. Option (B), something growing on a dead tree trunk, is an example of decomposition because the dead tree trunk is being broken down by decomposers, resulting in the growth of fungi and other organisms. Option (A), a dog eating dog food, is an example of consumption, not decomposition. Option (C), a lion eating a gazelle, is an example of predation, not decomposition. Option (D), a parrot eating bird seed, is an example of consumption, not decomposition.

This question tests our understanding of decomposition, which is the process of breaking down organic matter into simpler substances. Option (B), something growing on a dead tree trunk, is an example of decomposition because it involves the breakdown of the dead tree trunk by fungi or other decomposers. Option (A), a dog eating dog food, is not an example of decomposition as it is a simple act of consumption. Option (C), a lion eating a gazelle, is an example of predation or consumption, not decomposition. Option (D), a parrot eating bird seed, is also an example of consumption, not decomposition.

Option (A) is incorrect because a dog eating dog food is a form of consumption. Option (C) is incorrect because a lion eating a gazelle is a form of predation. Option (D) is incorrect because a parrot eating bird seed is a form of consumption.
